qas.question: Who created a law that did not allow Han Chinese to learn the beliefs of Tibetan Buddhism?
What years did the Yongle Emperor reign?
Who worked towards obtaining a extension of relations with Tibet?

context: However, the early <a0_0>Ming government<a0_0/> enacted a law, later rescinded, which forbade Han Chinese to learn the tenets of Tibetan Buddhism. There is little detailed evidence of Chinese—especially lay Chinese—studying Tibetan Buddhism until the Republican era (1912–1949). Despite these missions on behalf of the Hongwu Emperor, Morris Rossabi writes that <a2_0>the Yongle Emperor<a2_0/> (r. <a1_0>1402–1424<a1_0/>) "was the first Ming ruler actively to seek an extension of relations with Tibet."
